poem:
**A Festive Spread**

In the tapestry of an Italian feast,  
eggs devilled, and sausages embrace bacon,  
not merely ornaments but crescendos,  
angels and devils dance in pastry skirts.  
Mince tarts flaunt crowns of goose liver  
in a symphony of bites, where light  
counterpoints the richness,  
a whisper of harmony glowing amidst tradition.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Party starters: Jacob Kenedy’s Italian Christmas canapes – recipes I am evolving as a host, and coming to realise that those rich dishes that crown our festive tables shine brightest when surrounded by contrasting and lighter bites – before, around and after, rather than just on the day itself. I do enjoy angels and devils on horseback, devilled eggs, little sausages wrapped in bacon, mince tarts crowned with goose liver, fried breads and cheesy pizzette,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
